questions.question: FNAC is useful in all types of thyroid cancers except
questions.explanation: FNAC is not useful in the diagnosis of follicular carcinoma of thyroid as it cannot differentiatebetween benign and malignant follicular lesion. Trucut biopsy is used to differentiate betweenthem as follicular thyroid malignancy is defined by capsular and vascular invasion.Limitations of FNAC in thyroid disorders:⚫ Cannot distinguish between follicular carcinoma and adenoma•• Cannot distinguish between Hurthle cell carcinoma and adenoma.• Not useful in Reidel's thyroiditis

questions.question: What is the most common thyroid malignancy in iodine-deficient regions?
questions.explanation: Follicular thyroid carcinoma is the most common thyroid malignancy in iodine-deficient areas.Papillary thyroid carcinoma is the most common thyroid malignancy in iodine-sufficient areas,children, and radiation-exposed areas.

questions.question: A patient presented with a thyroid nodule. The USG showed an irregular hypoechoic masswith microcalcifications. Lymph nodes were not involved. FNAC showed a follicular neoplasmwith predominantly Hurthle cells. Intra-op frozen section confirms capsular invasion. What isthe most appropriate management?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Hurthle cell follicular carcinoma. The most appropriatemanagement is total thyroidectomy with prophylactic central neck dissection. Hurthle cellcarcinoma is a variant of follicular thyroid carcinoma.Hurthle CellsAs compared to follicular thyroid cancer, it has a poorer prognosis as it is more likely tometastasize. It is often bilateral and multifocal. The histological picture consists of predominantlyoxyphil (Hurthle, Askanazy) cells containing abundant mitochondria. options.A: Defective development of the fourth pharyngeal pouch
options.B: Metastatic thyroid cancer in lymph nodes

questions.explanation: Lateral aberrant thyroid almost always represents metastatic thyroid cancer in lymph nodes.Thyroid tissue situated lateral to the carotid sheath and jugular vein found along the course of thethyroglossal duct was previously termed lateral aberrant thyroid. It is associated with papillarythyroid cancer in the ipsilateral thyroid lobe.The image given below shows the lateral aberrant thyroid.

questions.question: Which type of thyroid cancer has the best prognosis?
questions.explanation: 318Patients with papillary thyroid carcinoma have an excellent prognosis with a >95% 10-yearsurvival rate.

questions.question: A 45-year-old man came to the surgery OPD with a midline neck swelling. He does not haveany other complaints. The patient had received chemoradiation for Hodgkin's lymphomanearly 20 years ago. On palpation, the mass is about 3 cm in size, non-tender, hard, fixed,and seems to arise from the right lobe of the thyroid. TSH levels were raised. A radioiodineuptake study showed cold nodule. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The history of radiation therapy to the head and neck for Hodkin's lymphoma and a cold noduleon radioiodine uptake scan are suggestive of papillary thyroid cancer.Radiation exposure is an identifiable aetiological factor in the development of differentiatedthyroid cancer (follicular and papillary thyroid cancer). The most important factor, however, isirradiation of the thyroid before 5 years of age.Thyroid lymphomas are non-Hodgkin's B-cell lymphomas. They present with B-symptoms likefever, night sweats, and weight loss in addition to neck swelling. Thus, thyroid lymphoma is anunlikely diagnosis. Thyroid lymphomas often develop in the setting of lymphocytic infiltration.

questions.question: A 45-year-old patient presents with diffuse enlargement of the thyroid gland. Laboratorystudies reveal low T3, T4, high TSH and the presence of anti-TPO antibodies. FNAC from thegland shows enlarged cells with abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm. Which of the followingmalignancies is commonly associated with this condition?
questions.explanation: The clinical case scenario is suggestive of Hashimoto's thyroiditis. Thyroid lymphoma ormalignant lymphoma is associated with long-standing Hashimoto's thyroiditis.Thyroid lymphomas are usually non-Hodgkin's lymphomas, often associated with long-standingHashimoto's thyroiditis (autoimmune lymphocytic thyroiditis).The clinical features include: B - symptoms i.e. fever, night sweats, and weight lossAs FNAC cannot characterize lymphoma, Tru-Cut biopsy is preferred. Chemotherapy andradiation therapy are often sufficient. Total thyroidectomy is indicated only in residual/recurrentdisease.A chemotherapy regimen (RCHOP) is the first line of management.R Rituximab--CyclophosphamideH-Hydroxydaunorubicin (Adriamycin)O Oncovin (Vincristine)-P Prednisolone-

questions.question: A 72-year-old woman has a history of papillary thyroid carcinoma left untreated for 2 years.She complains that the rapid enlargement in her neck swelling over the last month has madeit difficult for her to swallow and talk. What is the most likely diagnosis?

options.A: Local invasion of the surrounding structures

questions.explanation: An elderly woman with rapidly enlarging neck mass and dysphagia in the setting of an untreatedpapillary carcinoma suggests a diagnosis of anaplastic thyroid cancer.Anaplastic thyroid cancer, a poorly differentiated thyroid carcinoma, is the most aggressive cancerand has the worst prognosis of all thyroid malignancies.319It usually occurs in elderly females. The typical manifestation is an with rapidly enlarging neckmass, dysphagia, and cervical tenderness. Patients usually have a history of untreateddifferentiated thyroid carcinoma (DTC). Local invasion to the recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN)causes hoarseness. It may also cause tracheal obstruction. Distant metastasis is more common inthe lungs via the hematogenous route.Diagnosis is made by FNAC. However, trucut/open biopsy is frequently used to confirm thediagnosis in cases of doubt.Management:• If metastasis is absent: Total thyroidectomy + LN dissection• If metastasis is present: Palliative care with chemotherapy and radiotherapy• If tracheal obstruction: Isthmectomy to relieve obstruction

questions.question: A 34-year-old woman was brought in a dehydrated state and complains of loose stools. Onexamination, a tender neck swelling was found which was found to be present for 1 year.Histopathology of the swelling shows the following finding. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC). Histopathologyshows the presence of amyloid deposits that are derived from the altered calcitonin molecules.Medullary thyroid carcinoma is a tumor of parafollicular or C cells of the thyroid gland. They arederived from the neural crest cells of the ultimobranchial bodies.Most of the MTCs occur sporadically. However, around a quarter of the cancers are associatedwith familial MTC, MEN2A, and MEN2B.Patients with sporadic MTC present at an older age, whereas patients with familial MTC usuallypresent at a younger age. Features of MTC include:• Painful neck mass with cervical lymphadenopathy•Dysphagia, dysphonia or dyspnea if locally invaded• Diarrhoea due to increased intestinal motility by serotonin• Cushingoid habitus due to ectopic ACTH production• Metastasis is blood-borne• Microscopically, they consist of sheets of neoplastic cells separated by collagen and amyloidstromaIt is diagnosed by careful family history, physical examination, raised calcitonin, CEA levels, andfine-needle aspiration biopsy of the mass.Total thyroidectomy with central neck node dissection is the treatment of choice in MTC patients.External beam radiotherapy can be used in patients with unresectable tumors. Targeted therapycan be considered using vandetanib, sorafenib, sunitinib, and cabozantinib.Prophylactic total thyroidectomy should be considered within 5years of age in MEN2A mutationand within 1year of age in MEN2B mutation.320

questions.question: Choose the substances secreted by medullary thyroid carcinoma:
questions.explanation: Medullary thyroid tumors secrete calcitonin, serotonin, histaminadases, and CEA(carcinoembryonic antigen).

questions.question: A patient with medullary thyroid carcinoma is posted for surgery. He is nearly 6.5 ft tall, witha slender build and elongated digits. What is the screening test that should be donepre-operatively?
questions.explanation: This patient with medullary thyroid carcinoma and features of marfanoid habitus (very tall patientwith long, slender fingers and toes) is suggestive of MEN 2B syndrome. Such patients are to bescreened for pheochromocytoma by measuring urinary catecholamines.Pheochromocytoma, if present, should be treated first, and then MTC is to be treated next.A thyroid swelling with elevated calcitonin indicates a medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC). MTCcan either be sporadic (80%) or familial (RET gene mutation). In case of familial medullarythyroid carcinoma, stimulation with pentagastrin increases the release of calcitonin. This can beused for the screening of medullary thyroid carcinoma.MTC can be inherited as a part of autosomal dominant (AD) syndromes such as:• Familial MTC• MEN 2A• MEN 2BProphylactic total thyroidectomy should be considered within 5years of age in MEN2A mutationand within 1year of age in MEN2B mutation.Note: Serum calcium is measured to screen for parathyroid adenoma in MEN 2A.

questions.question: A patient is diagnosed with medullary thyroid carcinoma. Which of the following could beused to screen the rest of her family?
questions.explanation: Screening of patients with familial MTC was historically done using pentagastrin stimulation testfor calcitonin levels to make the diagnosis.Pentagastrin is a synthetic gastrin analogue. It acts on the CCK-B/gastrin receptor of the Ccells and increases the basal rate of calcitonin secretion.Basal calcitonin level = total C cell mass x rate of secretion.Medullary thyroid tumors secrete calcitonin and carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA), but also otherpeptides such as calcitonin gene-related peptide, histaminadases, prostaglandins E2 and F20, andserotonin.Another test that can be used for screening is calcium-stimulated calcitonin levels.

questions.question: Prophylactic thyroidectomy is indicated in patients with which of the following features:

options.B: Marfanoid habitus, multiple neuromas on the lip and familial pheochromocytoma,
options.C: Dense lymphatic infiltration of the thyroid detected on FNAC

questions.explanation: Prophylactic thyroidectomy is indicated in MEN 2B syndrome as they can develop medullarythyroid carcinoma. This syndrome manifests as:•⚫ Pheochromocytoma• Marfanoid habitusMucosal neuromas•Medullary thyroid cancer.Medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC) can be inherited as familial MTC, MEN 2A or MEN 2Bsyndromes. These conditions are autosomal dominant and occur due to RET proto-oncogenemutation. As almost all cases of MEN 2B develop medullary thyroid cancer, a prophylacticthyroidectomy may be performed even during infancy.Option A: The most common malignancy in thyroglossal cysts is papillary thyroid carcinoma. Insuch a case, Sistrunk operation with total thyroidectomy is considered.Option C: Hashimoto's thyroiditis shows dense lymphatic infiltration of the thyroid detected onFNAC which is treated with thyroxine. However, total thyroidectomy is performed in malignanttransformation to thyroid lymphoma.Option D: Upregulation of BRAF is associated with papillary thyroid carcinoma.

questions.explanation: Minor extrathyroidal extension detected only on histological examination is removed from thedefinition of T3 disease and therefore has no impact on either T category or overall stage.Differentiated Thyroid Cancer:• The age cutoff used for staging is increased from 45 to 55 years of age at diagnosis.• N1 disease no longer upstages a patient to stage III. If < 55 years of age at diagnosis, N1disease is stage I. If° 55 years of age, N1 disease is stage II.• T3a is a new category for tumors > 4 cm confined to the thyroid gland• T3b is a new category for tumors of any size demonstrating gross extrathyroidal extension intostrap muscles (sternohyoid, sternothyroid, thyrohyoid or omohyoid muscles)• Level VII lymph nodes, previously classified as lateral neck lymph nodes (N1b) is re-classified ascentral neck lymph nodes (N1a) to be more anatomically consistent and because level VIIpresented significant coding difficulties for tumor registrars, clinicians and researchers.• In differentiated thyroid cancer, the presence of distant metastases (M1) in older patients isclassified as IVB disease rather than IVC disease. Distant metastasis in anaplastic thyroid cancercontinues to be classified as IVC disease.Minimal or occult/microcarcinoma are tumors 1 cm or less in size. They have no evidence of localinvasiveness through the thyroid capsule or angioinvasion. Occult malignancies are usually notassociated with lymph node metastases. However, about 25% of patients with these tumors haveassociated occult lymph node metastases. These are nonpalpable and are found incidentally atoperative and histologic examinations or at autopsy.Anaplastic :• Unlike previous editions where all anaplastic thyroid cancers were classified as T4 disease,anaplastic cancers now use the same T definitions as differentiated thyroid cancer.• Intrathyroidal disease (T1-3a) is stage IVA•Gross extrathyroidal extension(T3b,T4) or cervical lymph node metastases (N1) is stage IVB•• Distant metastases (M1) are stage IVC323TNM staging7th AJCC (2010)8th AJCC (2018)Primary tumor(pT)TXToCannot be assessedNo evidence of cancer-do--do--do-T1T2T3T4Regional lymph nodes (pN)NXNoNiaN1bDistant metastasis (pM)Tumour ≤2 cm, intrathyroidalTia: ≤1 cm, intrathyroidalT1b:1-2 cm, intrathyroidal2-4 cm, intrathyroidal>4 cm limited to the thyroid.or any size with minimal extrathyroidal extension (muscle,soft tissue)T4a Invades subcutaneous tissue, larynx, trachea, esophagus, or RLNT4b Invades prevertebral fascia or encases carotid or mediastinal vesselsRegional lymph nodes cannotbe assessedNo lymph node metastasisPositive in level VI; questions.question: Which of the following will not be a treatment option for a pregnant patient with papillarythyroid carcinoma?

options.B: Total Thyroidectomy plus Lymph node dissection308

questions.explanation: Radioiodine ablation of thyroid is contraindicated in pregnant women due to risk of radiationexposure to the fetus.Therapeutic uses for radioactive iodine•In primary thyrotoxicosis after 45 years.• In autonomous toxic nodule after 45 years, it is useful as remaining gland still will functionadequately after radiotherapy.325• In follicular carcinoma of thyroid, after total thyroidectomy, if there are secondaries elsewhere inthe body, as in bones or lungs, then I131 is given.

questions.question: A patient with papillary thyroid carcinoma underwent total thyroidectomy with central neckdissection, a month ago. At present, a whole-body iodine scan is positive. What is the nextstep in management?
questions.explanation: Radio-iodine ablation is undertaken when a whole-body iodine scan is positive after a totalthyroidectomy for any differentiated thyroid cancer (papillary or follicular carcinoma).The presence of any metastatic or residual thyroid tissue after total thyroidectomy can be detectedby observing the uptake of radio-iodine in the entire body. To achieve effective uptake ofradio-iodine, TSH levels need to be greatly increased, for example, by withdrawing thyroxine afterthe surgery for 4-6 weeks.A positive whole-body iodine scan after total thyroidectomy indicates that there is either ametastatic or residual disease present. These patients are treated with I131 for radio-iodineablation.A negative scan means there is no metastasis or residual thyroid tissue. They are followed upregularly with serum thyroglobulin, TSH and USG-neck.If the tumour is resistant to radioiodine ablation, EBRT (external beam radiotherapy) is done.

questions.question: A whole-body iodine scan is not useful in patients with which thyroid malignancy?
questions.explanation: After a total thyroidectomy, a whole-body iodine scan is not useful for detecting residual thyroidtissue or metastasis in medullary thyroid carcinoma.Medullary thyroid carcinoma is a tumour of parafollicular or C cells. These cells which are derivedfrom neural crest cells, do not take up iodine.A whole-body iodine scan is useful in thyroid tumours derived from follicular cells that take upiodine.

questions.question: Which of the following scales consider the completeness of surgical resection to determine theprognosis of a patient with thyroid cancer?
questions.explanation: MACIS scale includes completeness of the original surgical resection to determine the prognosisof the thyroid cancer.Prognostic indicators of well differentiated thyroid cancers:• AGES system - Age, histologic Grade, Extrathyroidal invasion, and metastases and tumor Size.• AMES system - Age (men <40 years old, women <50 years old), Metastases, Extrathyroidalspread, and Size of tumors (< or >5 cm).• DAMES - DNA aneuploidy + AMES• GAMES - Grade + AMES• TNM staging - Tumor, Nodal status, Metastases.326• MACIS scale (postop modification) - distant Metastases, Age at presentation (<40 or >40years old), Completeness of original surgical resection, extrathyroidal Invasion, and Size oforiginal lesion (in centimeters).327
